lines.text: Enter Chamberlain, reading a letter

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: My lord, the horses your lordship sent for, with all the care I had, I saw well chosen, ridden, and furnished. They were young and handsome, and of the best breed in the north. When they were ready to set out for London, a man of my lord cardinals, by commission and main power, took em from me with this reason: His master would be served before a subject, if not before the king which stopped our mouths, sir. I fear he will indeed: well, let him have them: He will have all, I think.
Enter, to Chamberlain, NORFOLK and SUFFOLK

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Well met, my lord chamberlain.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Good day to both your graces.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: How is the king employd

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: I left him private, Full of sad thoughts and troubles.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Whats the cause

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: It seems the marriage with his brothers wife Has crept too near his conscience.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: No, his conscience Has crept too near another lady.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Tis so: This is the cardinals doing, the kingcardinal: That blind priest, like the eldest son of fortune, Turns what he list. The king will know him one day.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: Pray God he do! hell never know himself else.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: How holily he works in all his business! And with what zeal! for, now he has crackd the league Between us and the emperor, the queens great nephew, He dives into the kings soul, and there scatters Dangers, doubts, wringing of the conscience, Fears, and despairs and all these for his marriage: And out of all these to restore the king, He counsels a divorce a loss of her That, like a jewel, has hung twenty years About his neck, yet never lost her lustre Of her that loves him with that excellence That angels love good men with even of her That, when the greatest stroke of fortune falls, Will bless the king: and is not this course pious

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Heaven keep me from such counsel! Tis most true These news are every where every tongue speaks em, And every true heart weeps fort: all that dare Look into these affairs see this main end, The French kings sister. Heaven will one day open The kings eyes, that so long have slept upon This bold bad man.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: And free us from his slavery.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: We had need pray, And heartily, for our deliverance Or this imperious man will work us all From princes into pages: all mens honours Lie like one lump before him, to be fashiond Into what pitch he please.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: For me, my lords, I love him not, nor fear him theres my creed: As I am made without him, so Ill stand, If the king please his curses and his blessings Touch me alike, theyre breath I not believe in. I knew him, and I know him so I leave him To him that made him proud, the pope.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Lets in And with some other business put the king From these sad thoughts, that work too much upon him: My lord, youll bear us company

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Excuse me The king has sent me otherwhere: besides, Youll find a most unfit time to disturb him: Health to your lordships.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Thanks, my good lord chamberlain. Exit Chamberlain and KING HENRY VIII draws the curtain, and sits reading pensively

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: How sad he looks! sure, he is much afflicted.

lines.speaker: king henry the eighth
lines.text: Whos there, ha

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Pray God he be not angry.

lines.speaker: king henry the eighth
lines.text: Whos there, I say How dare you thrust yourselves Into my private meditations Who am I ha

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: A gracious king that pardons all offences Malice neer meant: our breach of duty this way Is business of estate in which we come To know your royal pleasure.

lines.speaker: king henry the eighth
lines.text: Ye are too bold: Go to Ill make ye know your times of business: Is this an hour for temporal affairs, ha Whos there my good lord cardinal O my Wolsey, The quiet of my wounded conscience Thou art a cure fit for a king. Youre welcome, Most learned reverend sir, into our kingdom: Use us and it. My good lord, have great care I be not found a talker.
Enter CARDINAL WOLSEY and CARDINAL CAMPEIUS, with a commission
To CARDINAL CAMPEIUS
To CARDINAL WOLSEY

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: Sir, you cannot. I would your grace would give us but an hour Of private conference.

lines.speaker: king henry the eighth
lines.text: [To NORFOLK and SUFFOLK] We are busy go.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: [Aside to SUFFOLK] This priest has no pride in him

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: [Aside to NORFOLK]             Not to speak of: I would not be so sick though for his place: But this cannot continue.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: [Aside to SUFFOLK]      If it do, Ill venture one haveathim.

lines.speaker: suffolk
lines.text: [Aside to NORFOLK]          I another.
Exeunt NORFOLK and SUFFOLK

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: Your grace has given a precedent of wisdom Above all princes, in committing freely Your scruple to the voice of Christendom: Who can be angry now what envy reach you The Spaniard, tied blood and favour to her, Must now confess, if they have any goodness, The trial just and noble. All the clerks, I mean the learned ones, in Christian kingdoms Have their free voices: Rome, the nurse of judgment, Invited by your noble self, hath sent One general tongue unto us, this good man, This just and learned priest, Cardinal Campeius Whom once more I present unto your highness.

lines.speaker: king henry the eighth
lines.text: And once more in mine arms I bid him welcome, And thank the holy conclave for their loves: They have sent me such a man I would have wishd for.

lines.speaker: cardinal campeius
lines.text: Your grace must needs deserve all strangers loves, You are so noble. To your highness hand I tender my commission by whose virtue, The court of Rome commanding, you, my lord Cardinal of York, are joind with me their servant In the unpartial judging of this business.

lines.speaker: king henry the eighth
lines.text: Two equal men. The queen shall be acquainted Forthwith for what you come. Wheres Gardiner

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: I know your majesty has always loved her So dear in heart, not to deny her that A woman of less place might ask by law: Scholars allowd freely to argue for her.

lines.speaker: king henry the eighth
lines.text: Ay, and the best she shall have and my favour To him that does best: God forbid else. Cardinal, Prithee, call Gardiner to me, my new secretary: I find him a fit fellow.
Exit CARDINAL WOLSEY
Reenter CARDINAL WOLSEY, with GARDINER

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: [Aside to GARDINER]  Give me your hand much joy and favour to you You are the kings now.

lines.speaker: gardiner
lines.text: [Aside to CARDINAL WOLSEY] But to be commanded For ever by your grace, whose hand has raised me.

lines.speaker: king henry the eighth
lines.text: Come hither, Gardiner.
Walks and whispers

lines.speaker: cardinal campeius
lines.text: My Lord of York, was not one Doctor Pace In this mans place before him

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: Yes, he was.

lines.speaker: cardinal campeius
lines.text: Was he not held a learned man

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: Yes, surely.

lines.speaker: cardinal campeius
lines.text: Believe me, theres an ill opinion spread then Even of yourself, lord cardinal.

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: How! of me

lines.speaker: cardinal campeius
lines.text: They will not stick to say you envied him, And fearing he would rise, he was so virtuous, Kept him a foreign man still which so grieved him, That he ran mad and died.

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: Heavens peace be with him! Thats Christian care enough: for living murmurers Theres places of rebuke. He was a fool For he would needs be virtuous: that good fellow, If I command him, follows my appointment: I will have none so near else. Learn this, brother, We live not to be gripd by meaner persons.

lines.speaker: king henry the eighth
lines.text: Deliver this with modesty to the queen. The most convenient place that I can think of For such receipt of learning is BlackFriars There ye shall meet about this weighty business. My Wolsey, see it furnishd. O, my lord, Would it not grieve an able man to leave So sweet a bedfellow But, conscience, conscience! O, tis a tender place and I must leave her.
Exit GARDINER
Exeunt
